text: Since NF-kappaB is central to the process of inflammation in RA , much research deals with the identification of the molecular triggers that activate NF-kappaB in RA .

It is well accepted that proinflammatory cytokines such as <extra_id_0> TNF <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> and IL-1 play an important role , and administration of <extra_id_0> TNF <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> antagonists is an effective treatment for severe RA ( reviewed in [ 9 ] ) .

<extra_id_0> TNF <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> and IL-1 are both very potent activators of NF-kappaB and it can be expected that NF-kappaB activation by these cytokines mediates most of their pro-inflammatory activities in RA ( reviewed in [ 3 ] ) .

NF-kappaB activation by <extra_id_0> receptor activator of NF-kappaB <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> ( <extra_id_0> RANK <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> ) , a TNF receptor family member , is important for osteoclastogenesis , and defects in proper <extra_id_0> RANK <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> - NF-kappaB signalling are likely to be involved in RA pathology and other diseases associated with bone loss [ 7 ] .

<extra_id_0> CD40 <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> is another <extra_id_0> TNF receptor family member <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> that is functionally expressed on a variety of cell types , including smooth muscle fibroblasts from normal and RA patients and RA synovial cells , B cells , macrophages , and dendritic cells , and can be upregulated by proinflammatory cytokines including <extra_id_0> TNF <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> [ 10 ] .

Binding of the <extra_id_0> CD40 ligand <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> ( <extra_id_0> CD154 <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> ) , which is transiently expressed on the surface of activated <extra_id_0> CD4 <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> + T cells , triggers NF-kappaB activation resulting in fibroblast proliferation and secretion of proinflammatory cytokines and chemokines , which contributes to joint destruction .

However , studies with antagonistic anti-CD40 or anti-CD154 antibodies led to the conclusion that <extra_id_0> CD40 <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> signals may be important at the initial stages of arthritis induction , but are not required once disease is established and pathogenic antibodies are already present [ 11 , 12 ] .

Enhanced expression of the TNF receptor family member <extra_id_0> B-cell activating factor <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> ( <extra_id_0> BAFF <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> ) , allowing the survival of autoantibody - producing B lymphocytes , is also characteristic for RA , and antagonists of <extra_id_0> BAFF <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> have been developed to counter RA [ 13 ] .

Finally , <extra_id_0> lymphotoxin beta receptor <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> signalling has been implicated in tertiary lymphoid organ formation at sites of chronic inflammation including RA [ 13 ] .
Toll-like receptors ( TLRs ) have been implicated in a variety of autoimmune diseases and are potential candidates for inducing NF-kappaB - dependent inflammation in RA .

In addition to microbial ligands , an increasing number of endogenous ligands - a group of proteins derived from host tissues and cells - have been reported as candidate activators of TLRs inducing so-called sterile inflammation ( reviewed in [ 14 , 15 ] ) .
TLRs are expressed in RA synovial tissues and various endogenous ligands are present within the inflamed joints of RA patients .
Moreover , animal models using TLR knockout mice or strategies to block TLR signalling clearly identify TLR - dependent inflammation as being important in the pathogenesis of the disease .

<extra_id_0> High mobility group box chromosomal protein 1 <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> ( <extra_id_0> HMGB1 <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> ) , a highly conserved <extra_id_0> chromatin component <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> that can be actively secreted by macrophages or passively released by necrotic cells , is one of the most putative endogenous <extra_id_0> TLR4 ligands <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> involved in RA pathology .

<extra_id_0> HMGB1 <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> is increased in RA synovial tissue and <extra_id_0> HMGB1 <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> neutralising antibodies or the antagonistic BoxA domain of <extra_id_0> HMGB1 <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> protect against collagen - induced arthritis in mice [ 16 ] .

<extra_id_0> Myeloid-related protein 8 <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> and <extra_id_0> myeloid-related protein 14 <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> , damage - associated molecular pattern molecules belonging to the S100 family of calcium - binding proteins , are also abundantly present in RA synovial fluid , and have been suggested to be involved in <extra_id_0> TLR4 <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> - induced chronic inflammation in RA [ 17 , 18 ] .

Other endogenous TLR ligands that may be involved in RA pathology are extracellular matrix components such as fibrinogen , <extra_id_0> fibronectin <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> , <extra_id_0> biglycan <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> , <extra_id_0> tenascin C <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> , and hyal-uronic acid fragments ( reviewed in [ 14 , 15 ] ) .
Together , these studies suggest that several TLR ligands in the inflamed joint tissue may contribute to NF-kappaB activation and inflammatory gene expression in RA .
